text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Wednesday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
ALL NEWSPAPERS

- Russia's new ambassador to Latvia, Alexander Udaltsov, presented his credentials to President Guntis Ulmanis. He said the Latvian-Russian intergovernmental commission, which has failed to start working, was one of his priorities. Udaltsov discussed a schedule of visits of Russian officials to Latvia in 1997 with Foreign minister Valdis Birkavs.
- Ulmanis met Guntar Krasts, current economy minister, late last night, nominated for the post of prime miniser by the third largest party Fatherland & Freedom.

- The three largest political forces failed to choose a common candidate for the PM's post. The Democratic party Saimnieks supports Andris Shkele, warning that it would go into the opposition if the president nominates somebody else. Latvia's Way was undecided and says it would respect any candidate chosen by the president. Fatherland & Freedom holds firm to its own candidate, Krasts.
- Ulmanis believes the new government may be formed without one of the three major factions.

- Prime Minister Shkele, if renominated, would like to forme the new government based on the three major parties and a coalition of smaller parties, with three ministerial portfolios reserved for each.
DIENA

- Head of the European Commission, Jacques Santerre, said that talks with Latvia are expected to start in late 1997 or early 1998, answering questions from Baltic MPs at the European Council Parliamentary Assembly.
NEATKARIGA RITA AVIZE
- Military co-operation between Latvia and the U.S. will be evaluated by a joint working group from both countries, meeting in Riga for a two-day conference.
BIZNES & BALTIYA
- Estonian Foreign Minister Toomas Henrik Ilves arrived on an official visit to Latvia.
- Some 19 parties and political organisations will compete in the coming elections to Riga City Council.
- The economy ministry is going to take over the foreign trade policy function from the foreign ministry, including the representation of Latvia in international trade organisations.
SM
- Draft regulations on cash transactions have been approved by the government economics and finance committee. All persons will be asked to declare transactions in excess of 1,000 lats per month.
DIENAS BIZNESS
- Industrial output in Latvia grew 1.1 percent in 1996, the statistics committee says.
- Some 95,400 job-seekers were registered in Latvia last year, of which 90,800 or 7.2 percent of the population have the status of unemployed.
- Savings Bank will have 18 percent of its shares sold in a public offer for privatisation vouchers.
-- Riga Newsroom +371 721 5240
